Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with excellent light absorption and superior catalytic performance in a wide wavelength range are regarded as ideal materials for realizing efficient focusing-light-driven photothermal catalysis. In this work, Co3O4-based catalysts with different morphologies, including prismatic Co3O4, flower-like Co3O4−M-2, spherical Co3O4−M-4 and another spherical variant Co3O4−M-20, were successfully prepared by finely tuning the concentration of the 2-methylimidazole (2-MI) ligand. Subsequently, the performance of these photothermal catalysts in the oxidation of ethyl acetate was exhaustively assessed under concentrated light conditions. Among various structures, the spherical Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibited a superior ethyl acetate conversion (approximately 90.5 %) and a higher light-induced temperature (200 °C) under a full spectrum of about 35.7 mW cm−2 (AM 1.5 G filter). This remarkable photothermal catalytic performance was primarily attributed to its exceptional light absorption ability and outstanding photothermal conversion efficiency. Furthermore, the spherical structure of Co3O4−M-4 boasted abundant active sites (Co3+ ions and Oads), larger specific surface area and higher defect structure compared with other catalysts, which facilitated effective contact with reacting gases and enabled the activation reaction. Ultimately, in situ DRIFTS analyses demonstrated that ethyl acetate oxidation over Co3O4−M-4 catalyst was initial oxidized to alcohol and acid intermediates, ultimately converted into CO2 and H2O. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Ethyl acetate 2-methylimidazole Co-MOF-74 derivatives Structure transformation Photothermal catalysis Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Ethyl acetate, a flammable and irritating oxygen-containing volatile organic compound (VOC) that is highly volatile in the air, can cause respiratory paralysis and other adverse health effects following prolonged inhalation exposure [1,2]. Nowadays, the prevalent technologies to eliminate VOCs are catalytic treatments relying on diversified environmentally functional materials, covering thermal catalysis [3], photocatalysis [4] and photothermal catalysis [5]. Light-driven photothermal catalytic technology, as an emerging and promising solution, cleverly utilizes the almost endless solar energy resources as the energy source, effectively alleviating the energy-intensive nature of thermal catalysis [6,7]. In the light-driven photothermal catalysis process, catalysts can effectively convert the absorbed light energy into thermal energy through various photothermal mechanisms, which provides the necessary thermal driving force for the subsequent degradation reaction of VOCs [6]. In addition, the highly reactive oxidative species (ROSs) generated during the photochemical reaction greatly facilitate the catalytic reaction [8,9]. In summary, in order to realize efficient light-driven photothermal catalysis reaction, the key lies in developing photothermal catalysts with strong solar absorptive capacity and excellent photothermal conversion efficiency. Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs), a class of crystalline porous materials, are formed through the coordination of metal-containing nodes with organic bridging ligands. Their highly tunable structures offer the possibility of dramatically broadening the range of photo-responses, while the unique crystalline properties and abundant porous structures create favorable conditions for the effective separation of photogenerated carriers [10]. Moreover, light irradiation activates the localized surface plasmon resonance effect in MOFs, enabling efficient photo-to-thermal energy conversion and significantly enhancing their photothermal efficiency [11]. Based on these significant advantages, numerous researchers have recently focused on exploring and advancing photothermal catalytic materials derived from MOFs [12–14]. For instance, Zhu et al. [13] skillfully used MOF to realize the in-situ transformation of metal Co to form a highly active Co-Co3O4 heterostructure during the photothermal process, which endowed the catalyst with excellent light absorption ability and stable photothermal performance. Chen et al. [14] fabricated a range of hollow NiO x /Co3O4 materials using MOF-templated approach, which demonstrated remarkable light utilization efficiency owing to their broad solar spectrum absorption and exceptional photothermal performance. In conclusion, different nanomaterials obtained via MOF precursors have better photothermal functional properties compared to initial components, and these derivatives exhibited highly structure-dependent physical and chemical properties [13,15]. Therefore, the implementation of precise controlling growth strategies for different MOFs sizes or shapes is very important to optimize MOFs and its derived materials with excellent catalytic properties and special chemical properties. Transition metal oxides (TMOs) with polymorphism and multivalency exhibit outstanding catalytic activity in removing various VOCs [6,16]. Among these oxides, black powder Co3O4 is considered an ideal candidate in the field of light-driven catalysis because of its exceptional light-absorbing capacity [17,18]. Unfortunately, conventional Co3O4 materials encounter huge barriers to performance enhancement, primarily due to their restricted morphological and dimensional. These limitations lead to accelerated recombination of photogenerated charge carriers and significantly reduce the number of accessible active sites for catalytic reactions [19]. Thus, it is particularly critical to use appropriate methods to prepare Co3O4 with the proper structure. Three-dimensional (3D) morphologies exhibit excellent catalytic performance through their unique structural advantages, such as a wide pore structure, extraordinary mass transfer efficiency and more exposed active site [20,21]. Strikingly, Co-MOFs have been proven to be attractive templates for the preparation of 3D Co3O4 structures [22,23]. Zhong et al. [23] synthesized 3D CoCO3 precursors with multiple morphological features derived from 1D Co-MOF-74 by employing different modulators, Co3O4 catalysts with corresponding morphological features were obtained after calcination. In addition, coordination modulations, synthetic process parameters and compositions have shown great potential in synthesizing MOFs crystals with different morphologies and sizes [24,25]. Based on the above considerations, this study achieved the synthesis of Co3O4 catalysts with diverse three-dimensional structures through the incorporation of 2-methylimidazole (2-MI) in a hydrothermal process. Subsequently, the activity of these photothermal catalysts for ethyl acetate oxidation was comprehensively investigated under concentrated light environment (AM 1.5 G filters, light intensity of 35.7 mW cm−2), the specific experimental setup is displayed in Fig. S1. Compared with prismatic Co3O4, flower-like Co3O4−M-2 and another spherical variant Co3O4−M-20, the spherical structure of the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibited a superior ethyl acetate conversion (approximately 90.5 %) and a higher light-induced temperature (200 °C). To thoroughly examine the microstructures and chemical compositions of these catalysts, a series of characterization techniques were employed, with particular focus on their light absorption ability and photothermal conversion performance. Finally, in situ DRIFTS was utilized to explore the degradation mechanism of ethyl acetate on the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst in detail. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Preparation of Co3O4 catalyst 1 mmol of 2,5-dihydroxyterephthalic acid (H4dhtp) and 4 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O were added to a 100 mL of mixed solvent system consisting of ethanol, water and N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) equal volume ratios. The above homogeneous solution was hydrothermally treated in a Teflon-lined autoclave at 100 °C for 24 h, followed by natural cooling to room temperature. The resulting solid was washed several times with ethanol and water, then dried at 100 °C for 12 h to yield the Co-MOF-74 precursor. Subsequently, the precursor was heated to 400 °C at 1 °C min−1 in air and held for 4 h, the final product was designated as Co3O4. 2.2 Preparation of Co3O4−M-X catalysts In this synthesis procedure, two separate solutions were prepared. Solution A was prepared by adding 1 mmol of 2-methylimidazole (2-MI) to 10 mL of mixed solvent of ethanol, water and DMF, while Solution B was prepared by dissolving 1 mmol of H4dhtp and 4 mmol of Co(NO3)2·6H2O in 100 mL of the same solvent mixture. Solution A was poured into solution B, and the subsequent synthetic protocol followed the previously described procedure for Co-MOF-74 precursor preparation, with the resulting product designated as Co-MOF-74-M-1. In addition, a series of analogous materials were synthesized by systematically varying the 2-MI content from 1 to 20 mmol (X = 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 10, and 20 mmol), maintaining identical synthetic conditions. Following calcination under the same thermal treatment parameters, the derived metal oxide products were correspondingly labeled as Co3O4−M-X, where X represents the initial molar quantity of 2-MI used in the synthesis. Detailed methodologies for the assessment of photothermal catalytic performance and material characterization are comprehensively described in the Supporting Information document. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characterization The structural properties of unmodified Co-MOF-74 and Co-MOF-74-M-X precursors were characterized using X-ray diffraction (XRD). Fig. 1 a demonstrates that these precursors with different 2-MI ratios exhibit two distinct and consistent diffraction peaks at 2θ angles of 6.7° and 11.7°, which accurately correspond to the (110) and (300) crystallographic planes of MOF-74 nanocrystal [26]. This observation indicates the series of catalysts maintains a high degree of structural consistency. However, it is remarkable that the diffraction peak intensity of Co-MOF-74-M-4 precursor is significantly weaker than that of the other precursors, indicating a more pronounced distortion in the lattice structure, accompanied by an elevated number of defects. The structural properties of Co3O4, Co3O4−M-2, Co3O4−M-4 and Co3O4−M-20 catalysts were also analyzed through XRD. As depicted in Fig. 1b, all Co3O4-based catalysts show highly consistent and well-characterized diffraction peaks, which are sharp and clearly distinguishable. Specifically, the major diffraction peaks located at 19.0°, 31.3°, 36.9°, 38.5°, 44.8°, 55.7°, 59.4° and 65.2° correspond precisely to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (422), (511) and (440) crystal planes of spinel Co3O4 phase (JCPDS card No. 42–1467) [27]. The result fully demonstrates that the as-synthesized Co3O4-based catalysts possess excellent crystallinity and high purity characteristics. 3.2 Microstructural analyses Fig. 2 presents the scanning electron microscope (SEM) graphs of unmodified Co-MOF-74 and Co-MOF-74-M-X precursors. As the concentration of 2-MI progressively increases, the precursors exhibit a significant morphological evolution, changing from their original prismatic morphology to the three-dimensional spherical architecture (Fig. 2a). The specific details of this transformation are evident in Fig. 2b-j. Fig. 2b reveals that pristine Co-MOF-74 without the influence of 2-MI shows an irregular prismatic morphology, with the diameter of individual prisms being 20 ∼ 40 μm and the length being 90 ∼ 130 μm. When a small amount of 2-MI (1 mmol) is added to the synthetic system, although the basic morphology of Co-MOF-74 does not change significantly, both its length and diameter are slightly decreased, exhibiting a certain trend of size adjustment (Fig. 2c). As the 2-MI concentration increases to 2 or 3 mmol, Co-MOF-74-M-2 and Co-MOF-74-M-3 products present unique flower-like structures assembled from prisms (Fig. 2d and e). When the 2-MI concentration increases to 4 mmol, Co-MOF-74-M-4 appears a new 3D microsphere morphology structure consisting of two small hemispheres assembled with obvious cracks on the surface, and the diameters of these microspheres are measured to be about 7 μm in Fig. 2f. Ultimately, as the 2-MI concentration continuously increases to 20 mmol, the overall morphology of the particles remains spherical, but their diameters gradually diminish and their surfaces grow smoother (Fig. 2j). This change further verifies the capacity of 2-MI concentration to meticulously modulate the morphologies and structures of Co-MOF-74-M-X catalysts. The Co3O4, Co3O4−M-2, Co3O4−M-4 and Co3O4−M-20 catalysts obtained by calcination at 400 °C were carefully characterized by SEM (Fig. S2). Notably, the above catalysts perfectly preserve the basic morphological structures of their respective precursors. Particularly, the SEM image of pure Co3O4 demonstrates its irregular prismatic morphology accompanied by cracked surfaces, with the diameter of a single prism being approximately 50 μm and the length reaching up to 300 μm (Fig. S2a). Looking further at Fig. S2b, the Co3O4−M-2 catalyst manifests a unique flower-like structure assembled from layered prisms, its length and width have significantly increased compared with pure Co3O4. Both Co3O4−M-4 and Co3O4−M-20 catalysts exhibit a uniform 3D spherical structure, but there are some differences in details (Fig. S2c, d). Co3O4−M-4 has a relatively smaller diameter and a more densely packed particle covering the catalytic surface, a feature that may positively affect its catalytic performance. To understand the morphologies and microstructures of as-prepared Co3O4-based catalysts, TEM and HRTEM techniques were used for exhaustive analyses, with the corresponding data presented in Fig. 3 . The TEM images reveal that the pure Co3O4 presents an irregular hexagonal prismatic morphology with a diameter of about 10 μm (Fig. 3a). Further observation by HRTEM indicates that Co3O4 catalyst exhibits well-defined lattice spacings of 0.464 and 0.242 nm, matching the d-spacings of the (111) and (311) crystal planes, respectively (Fig. 3e). In Fig. 3b, when the preparation conditions are adjusted, multiple hexagonal prisms with diameters ranging from 3 ∼ 5 μm aggregate and fuse to form a unique Co3O4−M-2 large flower-like structure. Detailed HRTEM examination of this structure identifies three characteristic interplanar distances including 0.485, 0.244 and 0.210 nm, matching the (111), (311) and (400) planes of the spinel structure, respectively (Fig. 3f). The Co3O4−M-4 and Co3O4−M-20 catalysts exhibit near-spherical morphologies with diameters of 2 ∼ 3 μm, and despite the similarity in macroscopic morphology, the microscopic lattice structures are distinctive (Fig. 3c and d). The Co3O4−M-4 catalyst shows interplanar distances of 0.213, 0.282 and 0.242 nm, indexed to the (400), (220) and (311) planes, respectively (Fig. 3g). In contrast, the Co3O4−M-20 catalyst demonstrates lattice fringes of 0.457, 0.243 and 0.278 nm, assigned to the (111), (311) and (220) crystallographic orientations (Fig. 3h). The above TEM and HRTEM observations not only reveal the structural features of Co3O4-based catalysts, but also verify that the morphologies and crystalline structures of these catalysts are being effectively modulated by altering the 2-MI ligand concentration. 3.3 Photothermal catalytic activity of catalysts The activity of the synthesized Co3O4-based photothermal catalysts was systematically assessed for ethyl acetate oxidation under controlled illumination conditions. The experiments were conducted using a light source with an intensity of 35.7 mW cm−2 (equivalent to a concentrated intensity of 0.91 W cm−2) in the presence of 500 ppm ethyl acetate, with particular emphasis on monitoring the conversion efficiency to CO2 as the primary reaction product. Fig. 4 clearly demonstrates substantial variations in ethyl acetate conversion efficiency among the synthesized Co3O4-based catalytic materials. The order of catalytic effect is Co3O4−M-4 (90.5 %) > Co3O4 > Co3O4−M-3 ≥ Co3O4−M-6 > Co3O4−M-2 ≥ Co3O4−M-8 > Co3O4–2-M-1 ≥ Co3O4−M-10 > Co3O4−M-20 (73.1 %) conversion (Fig. 4a). This trend clearly indicates that Co3O4−M-4 has excellent photothermal catalytic activity in ethyl acetate oxidation. Meanwhile, Co3O4−M-4 exhibits the highest surface light-induced temperature (approximately 200 °C) in Fig. 4b, which suggests its superior capability in solar energy harvesting and efficient thermal energy conversion. The thermal energy produced through this mechanism serves as a powerful driving force for facilitating subsequent photothermal catalytic processes. Water-tolerance test reveals that the ethyl acetate conversion rate remains above 82 % upon exposure to water vapor conditions (within 5 vol %), implying that the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst has good moisture resistance (Fig. S3a). Notably, the catalytic ability of Co3O4−M-4 for ethyl acetate is slightly decreased at about 3 % after adding the 300 ppm acetone into the reaction system (Fig. S3b). Additionally, the stability test results in Fig. 4c and d indicate that Co3O4−M-4 not only has excellent cycling performance, but also maintains a high catalytic activity under prolonged operation, fully demonstrating its viability as a promising candidate for photothermal catalytic VOCs oxidation systems. Comparing before and after the long-term testing, the XRD peaks of Co3O4−M-4 show no significant difference, indicating that the catalyst has outstanding structural stability during the photothermal catalytic reaction (Fig. S4). 3.4 BET and pore size analyses The specific surface area and pore structure parameters of Co3O4-based catalysts were investigated in depth using the N2 adsorption-desorption method, and the results are showed in Fig. S5 and Table 1 . Fig. S5a presents characteristic type-IV adsorption isotherms accompanied by H3-type hysteresis loops, indicating slit-like mesoporous architectures in these catalysts [28,29]. Simultaneously, the BJH pore-size distribution analysis shows that the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibits the smallest average pore size of only 13.96 nm among all tested catalysts. In addition, the specific surface area of the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst reached 44.23 m2 g−1, providing more available space for catalytic reactions [30,31]. Notably, Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibits a substantial pore volume of 0.392 cm3 g−1, representing approximately double the value observed for pristine Co3O4 (0.219 cm3 g−1). This enhanced porosity significantly facilitates gas phase reactant adsorption and diffusion within the catalytic system. These experimental findings clearly indicate that the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst offer great advantages in terms of reaction area and capacity. 3.5 Surface composition and oxygen vacancy analyses To obtain detailed information regarding surface chemical composition and elemental chemical states in the Co3O4-based catalysts, comprehensive X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses were performed. Examination of the Co 2p XPS reveals two main characteristic peaks, belonging to the Co 2p3/2 and Co 2p1/2 orbitals, accompanied by satellite features (Fig. S6). Furthermore, two major peaks are deconvoluted into four component peaks, attributed to the two oxidation states of Co3+ and Co2+. Precisely, the characteristic peaks observed at 779.20 and 794.25 eV contribute to Co3+ species [32], while those positioned at 780.71 and 795.83 eV correspond to the Co2+ species. Additionally, the other peaks at binding energies of 788.6 and 803.7 eV are assigned to the coupled satellite peak [2,33]. Based on the detailed analyses of the XPS data, the surface Co3+/Co2+ atomic ratios of as-prepared Co3O4-based catalysts are presented in Table 1. Obviously, the best-performing Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibits the highest Co3+/Co2+ ratio (approximately 2.12). This finding confirms that Co3+ serves as essential active centers, providing crucial for understanding the reaction mechanism of catalysts as well as optimizing catalytic performance. Similarly, the deconvolution of O 1 s XPS spectra for Co3O4-based catalysts reveals three distinct oxygen species (Fig. 5 a). The primary peak at 529.2 eV is belonging to lattice oxygen (Olatt), the secondary feature at 530.7 eV is attributed to surface adsorbed oxygen species (Oads), and the higher binding energy component at 532.1 eV corresponds to surface hydroxyl groups (O−OH) [6,34]. Through in-depth quantitative analyses of XPS spectra (Table 1), the highest percentage of Oads species on the Co3O4−M-4 surface is 25.36 %, while the Oads percentages of Co3O4−M-2, pure Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-20 are 22.12 %, 18.72 % and 18.42 %, respectively. From the above results, it is obvious that the best-performing Co3O4−M-4 possesses the highest percentage of Co3+ ions and the richest adsorbed oxygen (Oads) content. In general, the presence of abundant Co3+ ions typically creates charge imbalance within the catalyst's surface structure, thereby promoting the formation of coordinatively unsaturated sites and oxygen vacancies. These unique structural properties greatly facilitate the effective activation, strong adsorption and smooth migration of oxygen molecules and ultimately generate a high concentration of Oads [33]. Therefore, a higher ratio of Oads and Co3+ is directly associated with a higher level of oxygen vacancy content, which can be quantitatively validated through EPR spectroscopic analysis. As shown in Fig. 5b, Co3O4−M-4 and Co3O4−M-20 catalysts demonstrate similar EPR signals at g = 2.003, but the signal intensity of the former is significantly enhanced, which conclusively confirms that the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst indeed contains more abundant oxygen vacancies. Moreover, the intensity of EPR peak for Co3O4−M-4 catalyst has slightly increased after long-term testing, which may be attributed to the fact that photoexcitation facilitates the formation of oxygen vacancies (Fig. S7). 3.6 H2-TPR and O2-TPD analyses The oxidation–reduction properties of synthesized Co3O4-based catalysts were systematically examined through H2-TPR analysis, as illustrated in Fig. 5c. All catalysts demonstrate two distinct but overlapping H2 consumption features (RⅠ and RII) within the temperature range of 150 ∼ 500 °C. Specifically, the lower temperature RⅠ peak, centered at approximately 320 °C, represents the Co3+ to Co2+ reduction process, whereas the higher temperature RⅡ feature, observed near 420 °C, corresponds to the subsequent transformation of Co2+ to Co⁰ [35]. Notably, the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibits a significantly enhanced intensity of RⅠ reduction peak, strongly suggesting that the catalyst surface is enriched with more Co3+ ions. This finding is consistent with the previous results obtained by Co 2p XPS analysis, which further validates the unique advantages of Co3O4−M-4 catalyst in redox reactions. Besides, the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst stands out for its excellent low-temperature reduction performance, and the two reduction processes can be initiated and carried out efficiently at relatively low temperatures (317 °C and 418 °C). The oxygen storage characteristics of the synthesized catalysts were thoroughly investigated through O2-TPD measurements. The transformation of oxygen species typically proceeds in a well-defined sequence, progressing from O2 (ads) → O2 − (ads) → O − (ads) → O2− (latt) [36]. Fig. 5d reveals three distinct oxygen species (labeled OI, OII and OIII) can be clearly distinguished in three temperature intervals, 110 ∼ 250 °C, 250 ∼ 550 °C and above 550 °C. These intervals are associated with physically adsorbed oxygen molecules (O2), surface adsorbed reactive oxygen species (O2 − and O −) and lattice oxygen species (Olatt) [37]. Among them, the O2 − and O − species demonstrate enhanced surface affinity and serve as critical active components in facilitating catalytic processes. Therefore, the abundance of reactive oxygen species and their reducing properties can be understood by observing the intensity and position of the OII peaks. When comparing different catalysts, Co3O4−M-4 exhibits the highest desorption intensity and relatively lower desorption temperatures (about 368 °C), indicating abundant surface-active oxygen species and excellent low-temperature reduction performance. The mentioned advantages are significant for improving the efficiency and selectivity of the catalytic reaction. 3.7 Photoelectrochemical characteristics The optical properties and band structure of catalysts were systematically investigated through UV–vis DRS and Mott-Schottky. Notably, the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst has the highest light absorption intensity (Fig. 6 a). This remarkable enhancement can be primarily ascribed to its unique 3D microsphere structure, which effectively promotes the scattering and trapping of photons, thus enhancing the light absorption efficiency. The optical band gap energies (Eg) of the prepared catalysts were determined through tauc plot analysis, as shown in Fig. S8a. Therein, Co3O4−M-4 exhibits the narrowest Eg of 1.76 eV, suggesting that the minimal energy required for electron transitions between the valence and conduction bands, facilitating the migration of photogenerated carriers. In addition, the Mott-Schottky plots of Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-4 catalysts are indicated in Fig. S8b and Fig. 6b. The two Co3O4-based catalysts present distinctive “inverted V” profiles with alternating positive and negative slope regions, indicating that co-existence and atomic-level integration of both n-type and p-type semiconducting properties within the catalyst structure, suggesting the formation of p-n homojunction [38]. This structure can significantly enhance the spatial separation of photoinduced carriers by creating an internal electric field at the p-n interface [39]. Furthermore, the inherent lattice matching and continuity of band bonding in homojunctions enable the smooth migration of photoinduced carriers [40]. For the pristine Co3O4 catalyst, the EF values were measured as −0.75 V (n-type) and 1.36 V (p-type) relative to the Ag/AgCl reference. In contrast, the modified Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibited slightly shifted potentials of −0.77 V (n-type) and 0.99 V (p-type) under identical measurement conditions. When converted to the NHE scale, the corresponding Fermi levels (EFn and EFp) were calculated as −0.55 V and 1.56 V for Co3O4, and −0.57 V and 1.19 V for Co3O4−M-4, respectively. Typically, the conduction band (CB) of n-type semiconductor materials is 0.1 ∼ 0.3 V more negative than its corresponding EFn value, while the valence band (VB) of p-type semiconductor materials is 0.1 ∼ 0.3 V more positive relative to the EFp potential [41,42]. Based on this principle, the calculated ECB values for n-type Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-4 are −0.75 and −0.77 V, respectively, and the EVB values of p-type Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-4 are 1.76 and 1.39 V (versus NHE), respectively. Using the fundamental band structure relationship (ECB = EVB−Eg), the corresponding EVB of n-type Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-4 are calculated as 1.13 and 0.99 V, and the ECB of p-type Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-4 are −0.12 and −0.37 V (vs NHE). Extensive research has demonstrated that Co3O4 with a p-n heterojunction realizes charge transfer via the Z-scheme mechanism [2]. This mechanism is characterized by the fact that the electrons (e −) generated by photoexcitation in the p-type tend to recombine with the holes (h +) simultaneously photogenerated in the n-type semiconductor [43]. The Z-scheme transfer skillfully preserves the electrons of the n-type and the holes of the p-type, and significantly enhances the lifetime of charge carriers by effectively suppressing their rapid recombination at the generation site [44]. Combined with the O2/O2 − redox potentials, the final energy band diagrams of Co3O4 and Co3O4−M-4 catalysts are shown in Fig. 6e. The Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibits excellent redox properties and suitable energy band structure, which creates favorable conditions for molecular oxygen activation and significantly improved the photothermal catalytic efficiency. To validate the proposed mechanism of photoinduced charge carrier separation and transfer, TPC and EIS analysis were performed on the Co3O4-based catalysts (Fig. 6c and d). The Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibits highest photocurrent density compared to other catalysts, and this remarkable performance provides direct experimental evidence of the material's superior ability to promote the efficient migration of photoinduced charge carriers [45,46]. Further, the charge transfer efficiencies of the different catalysts can be observed by EIS analysis (present as Nyquist diagram). Co3O4−M-4 catalyst presents the smallest arc radius, verifying that the catalyst has the minimum charge transfer resistance (Fig. 6d) [47,48]. The above experimental findings not only verify the advantages of Co3O4−M-4 catalyst in promoting rapid charge transfer, but also demonstrate that it effectively restrains the complexation of photogenerated electrons and holes. These advantages significantly enhance the quantum yield of photogenerated carriers and establish a solid foundation for the catalyst's efficient application in photothermal catalytic reactions. 3.8 In situ DRIFTS and mechanism analyses To gain fundamental insights into the key reaction intermediates and underlying mechanistic pathways, in situ DRIFTS measurements were conducted on the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst under both dark and illuminated conditions (Fig. 7 ). The different characteristic spectral bands pinpoint the respective reaction intermediates. Specifically, the characteristic vibrational modes observed at 1098, 1262 and 1325 cm−1 can correspond to specific molecular vibrations of ethanol, respectively corresponding to the υ(CO), υ(CC) and δ(OH) modes, revealing the presence of ethanol as a reactant or intermediate [49–51]. Meanwhile, the weaker bands observed at 1026 and 1123 cm−1 are contributed to υ(OH) and δ(OH) stretching vibrations of methanol, which further enriches the information about possible alcohol intermediates in the reaction pathway [52]. Three distinct absorption peaks centered at 1410, 1444 and 1543 cm−1 are identified, which can be attributed to characteristic vibrational modes of carboxylate groups, specifically corresponding to δ(OH), νs(COO−) and υas(COO−) vibrations, respectively [53,54]. Additionally, the 1203 cm−1 band corresponds to υ(CCC) vibrations in methyl ethyl ketone [55], while the stronger 1726 and 1757 cm−1 bonds represent υ(C = O) and υas(C = O) vibrations in aldehyde species, respectively [56]. The in situ DRIFTS spectral profiles of the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst under a 500 ppm ethyl acetate/N2 gas mixture are presented in Fig. 7a and b. Under dark conditions, ethyl acetate is oxidized to alkoxyl and carboxylates through the breaking of ester bonds (−COO−). Upon the introduction of light irradiation, ethyl acetate and alkyd derivatives are converted to carboxylic acid species. As a result, the intensity of carboxylic acids in the spectra is significantly enhanced, which also indicates that carboxylic acids are an important intermediate in the photothermal catalytic process [2]. Furthermore, it is noteworthy that a weak new peak belonging to methanol is detected at the 1026 cm−1 position. This observation signifies that lattice oxygen actively participates in the reaction and further oxidizes ethanol to form small molecules of methanol under light conditions [57]. A similar evolution of intermediate products can be clearly observed under ethyl acetate/air atmosphere, in which the content of alkoxy groups and carboxylates steadily increases over time (Fig. 7c and d). Notably, the production of aldehydes is a key difference compared to the above ethyl acetate/N2 conditions, which is attributed to the incomplete nature of the oxidation reaction during ethanol decomposition [53]. When the light irradiation is introduced, the peak change in the DRIFTS profiles is particularly significant. As a result of further decomposition of ethanol and acetic acid under light conditions, the intensity of specific bands (e.g. 1325, 1410, 1444 and 1543 cm−1) is weakened compared to the ethyl acetate/N2 atmosphere. At the same time, new characteristic peaks belonging to formic acid, ethanol, methanol, methanol, methyl ethyl ketone and aldehydes appear. Therein, the presence of methanol and formic acid confirms the breaking of the CC bond in the ethanol and acetic acid molecules, which is a sign of a deep oxidation reaction. In addition, the generation of methyl ethyl ketone may be a result of the breakage of the characteristic ester bond (−COO−) of the ethyl acetate molecule under photoexcitation. These experimental results demonstrate that the oxygen vacancies on the Co3O4−M-4 surface efficiently activate gaseous O2 to generate reactive oxygen intermediates (O2 −) under light irradiation, leading to the complete mineralization of ethyl acetate into CO2 and H2O. In situ DRIFTS outcomes demonstrate that adsorbed ethyl acetate molecules on the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst surface mainly decomposed into ethanol and acetic acid in the presence of only lattice oxygen. When O2 molecules exist in the reaction system, oxygen vacancies in the catalysts adsorb and activate O2 molecules, enabling their participation in the reaction and driving the deep degradation of ethyl acetate. It can be subdivided into the following steps (Fig. 7e), (і) the ethyl acetate molecule first breaks at its −COO− bond to produce ethanol and acetic acid. It is worth noting that ethanol intermediate could further convert into acetaldehyde due to the incomplete oxidation, and then decomposes into acetic acid. (ii) Subsequently, the formed ethanol, acetaldehyde and acetic acid generated in the previous step are further oxidized to methanol and formic acid in the strong presence of reactive oxygen species. This step marks a further deepening of the degradation process and a further shortening of the carbon chain length of the products. (iii) Finally, methanol and formic acid are completely degraded to CO2 and H2O under continuous oxidation, this step is the end point of the degradation process and achieves the complete mineralization of organic matter. It is also worth mentioning that there is a possibility of generating methyl ethyl ketone during the degradation of ethyl acetate, which is further decomposed to produce acetaldehyde under specific conditions. 4 Conclusions In this study, prismatic Co3O4, flower-like Co3O4−M-2, spherical Co3O4−M-4 and another spherical variant Co3O4−M-20 were successfully synthesized by a double ligand strategy, especially for crucial changing the concentration of 2-MI ligand. The photothermal catalytic performance of these catalysts on ethyl acetate oxidation was investigated under focused light conditions. Compared with other catalysts, the spherically structured Co3O4−M-4 catalyst demonstrated excellent ethyl acetate conversions (about 90.5 %) and the highest light-induction temperature (approximately 200 °C) when irradiated by simulated sunlight (light intensity of 35.7 mW cm−2 with an AM 1.5 G filter). This remarkable photothermal catalytic performance was primarily attributed to its outstanding light absorption capacity and superior photothermal conversion efficiency. Furthermore, the Co3O4−M-4 catalyst had the advantages of abundant active sites (Co3+ ions and Oads), high defect structure and large specific surface area, which could effectively contact with the reacting gases and carry out the activation reaction. Finally, the in situ DRIFTS results revealed the decomposition pathway of ethyl acetate over Co3O4−M-4 catalyst was first decomposed into alcohols and acid intermediates, and finally converted into CO2 and H2O. This finding not only provides a novel conceptual framework for designing MOFs materials with sophisticated hierarchical structures, but also provides critical reference and lesson for improving the efficiency of light-driven photothermal catalytic VOCs oxidation. coredata.dc:description: Metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with excellent light absorption and superior catalytic performance in a wide wavelength range are regarded as ideal materials for realizing efficient focusing-light-driven photothermal catalysis. In this work, Co3O4-based catalysts with different morphologies, including prismatic Co3O4, flower-like Co3O4−M-2, spherical Co3O4−M-4 and another spherical variant Co3O4−M-20, were successfully prepared by finely tuning the concentration of the 2-methylimidazole (2-MI) ligand. Subsequently, the performance of these photothermal catalysts in the oxidation of ethyl acetate was exhaustively assessed under concentrated light conditions. Among various structures, the spherical Co3O4−M-4 catalyst exhibited a superior ethyl acetate conversion (approximately 90.5 %) and a higher light-induced temperature (200 °C) under a full spectrum of about 35.7 mW cm−2 (AM 1.5 G filter). This remarkable photothermal catalytic performance was primarily attributed to its exceptional light absorption ability and outstanding photothermal conversion efficiency. Furthermore, the spherical structure of Co3O4−M-4 boasted abundant active sites (Co3+ ions and Oads), larger specific surface area and higher defect structure compared with other catalysts, which facilitated effective contact with reacting gases and enabled the activation reaction. Ultimately, in situ DRIFTS analyses demonstrated that ethyl acetate oxidation over Co3O4−M-4 catalyst was initial oxidized to alcohol and acid intermediates, ultimately converted into CO2 and H2O.
